abstract.p: Suzaan Boettger letter mocks Michael Heizer's claims of contributions to early contemporary Land Art, in Dec 12 (1999) article; photo (S)

block.p: Michael Heizer was a major contributor to the earliest contemporary Land Art, but not for the reasons he offered Michael Kimmelman [''A Sculptor's Colossus of the Desert,'' Dec. 12]. Yes, Mr. Heizer went to Western deserts with Walter De Maria and Robert Smithson, but he hardly ''brought them west,'' as Mr. Kimmelman writes. Smithson had traveled the West as a child and as a young man, and Mr. De Maria grew up in California.

Michael Heizer was a major contributor to the earliest contemporary Land Art, but not for the reasons he offered Michael Kimmelman [''A Sculptor's Colossus of the Desert,'' Dec. 12]. Yes, Mr. Heizer went to Western deserts with Walter De Maria and Robert Smithson, but he hardly ''brought them west,'' as Mr. Kimmelman writes. Smithson had traveled the West as a child and as a young man, and Mr. De Maria grew up in California.

As with so many of Mr. Heizer's claims, his reference to Smithson and others associated with Earthworks as ''high-speed hustlers'' and ''academics who did not do a good historical job'' serves as both a mirror of this artist's own actions and a window onto his worldview.

It's too bad Mr. Heizer believes that there is so little recognition to go around that he must slander others to promote himself, and it's too bad there are critics quite willing to authorize Mr. Heizer's fantasies of not-only-sculptural grandeur.
The writer is the author of ''Earthworks: Art and the Landscape of the Late 60's,'' to be published by the University of California Press.
